text: The next morning. OLIVER shows off his newly acquired tal with a soft-boiled egg, neatly shearing off the shell. He looks a bit hung-over, with circles under his eyes.
(in something of an antic mood we haven’t seen before, self-mocking) We almost did it. Marzia and me.
(from behind his paper, and raising his eyebrows) And why didn’t you?
Dunno.
(half-comforting, half- mocking) Better to have tried and failed...
All I had to do was find the courage to reach out and touch, she would have said yes.
(seemingly off-hand) Try again later. ANNELLA comes in and while she is seating herself, asks:
Try later, what? PROFESSOR PERLMAN and OLIVER laugh, then the Professor changes the subject.  37 26.

I’d like that very much.
Can’t I come too?
On condition that you remain silent.
(teasing) Silent as in too many opinions on things, or silent as in Security: not telling anybody what fabulous things have been dug up?
Nothing is being dug up. It’s what has been brought up - out of the water. OLIVER looks awed.
Later. ANCHISE is wiping the windshield of the Perlmans’ ELIO comes out just as CHIARA arrives on her bike. She as him where Oliver is.

(in French) On va au lac de Garde avec mon pére. Il veut montrer 4 Oliver l'endroit ot ils draguent. (We’ re going to Lake Garda with dad. He wants to show Oliver where they’ re dredging.) CHIARA is disappointed.

(in French) Il est a4 l'intérieur, il aide mon pére. Tu étais incroyable sur la piste, hier soir. (He’s inside helping dad. You were great on the dance floor last night.)

(in French) Tu veux jouer les entremetteurs? (What are you trying to do, fix us up?) She leaves him and goes into the house. ELIO gets in the seat of the car and waits. Then OLIVER and CHIARA come ou They speak for a moment, standing close. She kisses him o the cheek, then gets on her bike and takes off. OLIVER gets into the front seat of the car, but ELIO tell him to sit in the back.

Dad always sits up front with Anchise to navigate. OLIVER gets in the back next to ELIO. He watches CHIARA riding away. ELIO (CONT’D) She seems to like you a lot - She’s more beautiful than she was last year. OLIVER doesn’t respond. ELIO (CONT’D) I saw her naked on a night swim. She has a great body. OLIVER turns to look at ELIO, surprised.
Are you trying to make me like her? While talking their bare legs briefly collide.  38 39 28.
What would be the harm in that?
No harm. Except I like to go at it alone, if you don’t mind. There is a long pause as PROFESSOR PERLMAN comes out and speaks to ANCHISE.
(to Anchise) Guido io oggi, non ti preoccupare. Non fare quella faccia Anchise! prenditi il pomeriggio libero. (I think I will drive myself today. Anchise, don’t be so upset! take the afternoon off.)
Don’t play at being the good host, just don’t. PERLMAN gets in the front seat. As there seems to be a te silence behind, he turns around as the engine starts.
What’s going on, boys? Oliver, come sit up front and be my navigator. OLIVER smiles at Elio as if to say: "See?"

PERLMAN drives the car through the countryside, OLIVER ha map open on his legs. Hot air blows in through all the op windows. They are silent as the news plays on the radio, reporting on the P2 Masonic lodge. ELIO looks outside but his attention is drawn to Oliver’s neck.

PERLMAN, OLIVER and ELIO walk through the magnificent rui of the roman villa overlooking Lake Garda, the Grotte di Catullo (Caves). Perlman is explaining to Oliver that onl part of the archaeological treasures of this area has com light.  40 41 42 29.

The ship went down in 1827 on the way to the villa of Count Lechi here on this island. A delegation of archaeologists is waiting for them. The senior member rushes up to PERLMAN and greets him. They a gather in the small beach that is dominated by the ruins. Perlman is showed with the arm of a statue. He is very excited.

A salvage operation is in progress. Some small boats surr a floating platform. At the center of the platform is a winch. There are scuba divers and other people all around PERLMAN goes in the water and walks through the shallows towards an inflatable boat that is standing by, ready to him to the platform. ELIO is proud of his father and like Oliver is excited. The professor gestures them to join hi

PERLMAN, OLIVER, ELIO and other men are on the boat, now to the platform. At the center of the platform below the cable of the winc a large opening. A steel cable is lowered into the water steadied by the site workers. The wait. Finally the cable is pulled back up - it pulls antique statue out of the water. PERLMAN, edging closer, watches the operation minutely. A bronze Boxer slowly com up through the opening in the platform, secured by the hu divers, and as it does a chain-metal trap inches undernea it to prevent it from falling back into the water if something should go wrong. The statue, missing its left arm but otherwise intact, is an athlete, a boxer, naked, a kind of finger-less glove a wrist-strap. Like the damaged arm and gloved hand, the st is encrusted with the lake water deposits of a century. I still possible to admire the beauty of the athlete’s face set with enamelled eyes that seem to be staring straight through the murky water at his rescuers. A photographer i fins goes in for a close-up. There is great excitement.
Later, back on the beach. The bronze has been dried and cleaned. PERLMAN is speaking in Italian with the other me and women who took part in the operation, and who are analyzing the find.  43 44 30.
Dad, why are we only finding him now?

A good question. His partner - they’re a pair - is in the Vatican. There are four known sets, after the Praxiteles originals. This fellow is Number Three. The Emperor Hadrian had a pair, dug up at Tivoli, but one of the more philistine of the Farnese popes melted them down and had them recast as a particularly voluptuous Venus that was traded to Napoleon later on.
I guess they didn’t need two pairs.

No.. The sun is setting, casting its last rays on the long-mis athlete for the first time in more than a hundred years. Armed Carabinieri assemble to guard it for the night. PERLMAN (CONT’ D) Who would like to go for a swim before we head back?

They swim in a little cove not far from the rig that pull up the bronze Boxer. It is almost dark, with a cloud stre sky reflected in the water. The lights on the rig go on, including a big floodlight. The lake is surrounded by sno capped mountains. Treading water, PERLMAN says to ELIO and OLIVER, who are nearby, and referring to the armed guards left on the floating platform with the athlete:
They’ re all such rogues. Our boxer could be on a plane to the Geneva antiquities market tonight for all I know. They laugh. The moon is beginning to rise over the water.
The same moon shines on the water of the river where MARZ waits for ELIO, as promised. She looks at her wristwatch.  45 46 47 48 49 31.
The Perlman car reaches the villa and all get out. ELIO r around the house to get his bike and wheels it out on to road.
I have to go!! The two men smile at Elio's passionate haste.
Are you going too?
No Prof, I have to work.
How about a drink to celebrate the day?

That would be great. INT. OLIVER’S ROOM - PERLMAN VILLA - NIGHT 46 OLIVER is sitting at his desk in his boxer shorts only, working; only the desk light is on. A lit cigarette betwe his fingers. A radio plays some summer music at a low vol Oliver wraps up his corrections on a page and marks it: “ be typed”. EXT. ROAD / RIVER -— NIGHT 47 ELIO is riding on his bike on the way to the river, tryin catch his date with Marzia. When he gets there, no one is waiting. He calls her name. There is a soft sound, little waves lapping on the river shore. The moon is brighter th ever and has risen considerably.
The following day. A thunderstorm and heavy rain dashes t plants in the garden and pours from the roof spouts.
Inside the villa the three PERLMANS are sitting on a row big couch as the lights flicker.  32.
Have you seen my Heptameron?
It must be over there... ANNELLA finds the book.

This version is in German, but I’1ll translate: Ein gut aus sehender junger Ritter ist wahnsinnig verliebt in eine Prinzessin. Sie auch ist in ihn verliebt. “,..A handsome young knight is madly in love with a princess. She too is in love with him... ...obwohl es so scheint, als sei sie sich nicht vollig ihrer eigenen Liebe bewusst. ...though she seems not to be entirely aware of it. Despite the friendship... Freundschaft... that blossoms between them, or perhaps because of that very friendship, the young knight finds himself so humbled and speechless that he is totally unable to bring up the subject of his love. One day he asks the princess point-blank: Ich bitte euch ratet mir was besser ist... reden oder sterben. ‘Is it better to speak or die’. The lights suddenly all go out in the house; the music fr long-playing record dies to a stop. There is a shout in t kitchen, MAFALDA.
(still thinking about the Knight and the princess) I’d never have the courage to ask such a question.

We were your age once. The things you feel and think only you have felt, believe me, We’ve suffered through all of them, and more than once - some you never get over and others you’re as ignorant about as you are today.  50 51 52 33.

(nodding in agreement) Make new friends if the old ones don’t interest you but stop haning around the house all the time. Books, books, books, always books, et toutes ces partitions... (is all those score books)... play more tennis, go dancing more often with Chiara and Marzia - tu les aimes no? (you like them, don’t you?) Get to know people...

Find out why others are so necessary in life and not just foreign bodies to be sidled up to. They have been sitting in near darkness. The rain beats against the window panes. ANNELLA spreads an afghan over knees of the three of them, saying “It’s getting cold in here”. Just then the lights come back on and the music resumes. She looks at her son and runs her fingers throug his hair tenderly.
Fai anche pazzie se devi. (Do crazy things if you must.) (Fais des folies, s’il le faut.)

The next day. The storm has passed, leaving a coolness. E is playing the piano. He is immersed in thought, his mind elsewhere. He breaks off, gets up, moves from room to roo downstairs. The kitchen is empty as well. It’s the hour o siesta. Oliver’s bike is missing.

ELIO goes back inside and up the stairs very quietly and along the corridor he shares with Oliver. He approaches Oliver’s door like a detective looking for clues. He is a to open it when he hears the sounds of someone coming up back stairs; he opens the door to his own room instead, a walks in. INT. CORRIDOR / ELIO’S - OLIVER’S ROOM / SHARED BATHROOM

MAFALDA appears in the corridor, holding the laundry of t two young men. She brusquely opens Oliver’s door, puts Oliver’s shorts, socks, handkerchiefs, maybe the blue “pillowy” shirt, on his dresser. She goes out, then knock Elio’s door.  53 54 55 34. ELIO says “Avanti” and she goes in with a pile of the sam sort of clothes belonging to him. He’s lying on his bed, pretending to read a book. She leaves; he can hear her retreating footsteps. When she is safely gone he stealthi goes into Oliver’s room through the bathroom they share. looks around Oliver’s room. INT. OLIVER’S ROOM - PERLMAN VILLA - DAY 53 He goes to the little pile of laundry and examines it, se the folded boxer shorts (or Jockey) - passes his finger t over them, then goes to the closet. Hanging on a hook is red bathing suit. He picks it up - it’s dry - and brings to his face. He rubs his face inside it, smelling it, loo inside it as if searching for something, kisses every inc it, licks the inside of the supporter as if trying to fin taste of Oliver. ELIO quickly slips out of his own bathing suit and pulls Oliver’s. He undoes Oliver’s bed and gets into it, puttin the pillow over his face and kissing it savagely, smellin again and again, searching for Oliver’s scent, then wraps bare legs around it. Suddenly he hears the sound of a bicycle approaching goes look out the window. He can just partly see OLIVER leavin his bike by a wall and coming in the villa. Elio removes Oliver’s trunks and tidies up the bed, exiting the room.

ELIO runs towards the window at the end of the corridor a looks down from it. No one. Finally Oliver appears going the steps and moving towards the stone trough. Elio runs the stairs and goes down to the ground floor.
Later. ELIO is sitting under the trees with his score boo open. OLIVER sits on the edge of the stone trough with hi feet in the water, he is wearing his straw hat.
My mom’s been reading this 16th century French romance. She read some of it to my Dada and I the day the lights went out.
About the knight who doesn’t know whether to speak or die? You told me already.
Yes.  35.
Well, does he or doesn’t he?
Better to speak, she said. But she’s on her guard. She senses a trap somewhere.
So does he speak?
No, he fudges.
That figures. Listen, I need to pick up something in town.
I’ll go, if you want me to. Beat.
Let’s go together.
Now?
Why, have you got anything better to do?
No. OLIVER puts some pages of his manuscript into his old fra book bag.

So let’s go. ELIO puts down his fountain pen, closes his score book, a in doing so knocks a half-full glass of lemonade onto the grass. It doesn’t break. OLIVER, who is close by, comes o picks it up, and puts it back where it was.
You didn’t have to. Creating a little pause before replying, for emphasis.
I wanted to.  36.
On the way to the shed to collect their bikes, they pass ANCHISE, who hands OLIVER his bike with a wry smile. OLIV smiles back.
(Mixture of Italian and English) (I straightened the wheel. It took some doing. I also put air in the tires.)

Grazie. ELIO and OLIVER reach the road, where they pause for a moment. OLIVER pulls up his shirt and pulls down the top his shorts to expose a big scrape and bruise on his left OLIVER (CONT’D) (showing ELIO his wound) I fell the other day on the way back and scraped myself pretty badly. Anchise insisted on applying me some sort of witch’s brew. He also fixed the bike for me. ELIO leans over closely to see Oliver’s scrape, which is smeared with a black unguent.
Does he give you the creeps?
Who?
That’s what my aunt says. Anchise.
(pulling his clothes together and turning out on the road) Of course not. Just a lost soul, really, like most of us.
They arrive on their bikes at the little town square. OLI buys a pack of cigarettes, Gauloises. He lights one up, t offers one to ELIO.
You want to try one?  37. ELIO nods and OLIVER cups his hands very near Elio’s face lights his cigarette. OLIVER (CONT’D) Not bad, right?
(drawing on it) Not bad at all. I thought you didn’t smoke.

I don’t. (taking another drag) They walk their bikes towards the little World War I memo in the center of the square which is dedicated to the you of the town who perished in the Battle of Piave. They pau moment to read the plaque. OLIVER (CONT’D) World War II? Did the Allies fight near here?
No. This is World War I. You’d have to be at least eighty years old to have known any of them.
Is there anything you don’t know? I never heard of the Battle of Piave. ELIO looks at OLIVER. He hesitates, then bursts out:
I know nothing Oliver. Nothing, just nothing.
(looking at him steadily You know more than anyone around here.
If you only knew how little I know about the things that really matter.
What things that matter? ELIO looks him straight in the eye for once, summoning up courage:
You know what things. By now you of all people should know.  Silence. 38.
Why are you telling me all this?
Because I thought you should know.
(he repeats ELIO’s words slowly, playing for time as he considers them) Because you thought I should know.

Because I want you to know (blurting it out) Because there is no one else I can say this to but you. There is a magnificent view. A tiny bus works its way uph with some bikers struggling behind it. To buy time, OLIVE turns to look at it before replying:
Are you saying what I think you’re saying?

Yes. Now that he’s spilled the beans at last, ELIO takes on th laid-back, mildly exasperated air which the felon has, on he surrendered to the police, when he confesses how he ro the store. OLIVER looks at ELIO for a long moment, then gestures tow the shop front where he takes his manuscript to be typed
Wait for me here. Don’t go away.

(looking at OLIVER with a confiding smile) You know I’m not going anywhere. Two buses stop nearby to unload their passengers - older women arriving from adjoining villages to shop. ELIO turn read the names listed on the monument. OLIVER returns.

(frowning) They’ ve mixed up my pages and now they have to retype the whole thing. So I have nothing to work on this afternoon. Which sets me back a whole day. Damn!  58 39. ELIO looks as if it has been his fault the typist made a mistake.
I wish I hadn’t spoken.
I’m going to pretend you never did.
(unfazed) Does this mean we’re on speaking terms - but not really? OLIVER thinks about this.
Look, we can’t talk about such things, we really can’t. He slings his bag with its papers around him and the two off down hill.

Now that ELIO has laid his cards on the table, the scener and the fine weather buoy his spirits. They ride together the empty country road that at this time of day is all fo them. The sun pounds exposed patches along the way, expos the undergrowth. Thirsty they stop by a factory. They loo for water and in the factory Oliver is surprised to see a Mussolini picture hanging on a wall. They laugh. Later, at another crossroad.

Follow me. I’11 show you a spot visitors have never seen. That is, if you have time. ELIO turns off into a little path towards some spring wat ponds surrounded by willow trees. ELIO leans his bike aga one of them, followed by OLIVER. ELIO (CONT’D) This is my spot. All mine. I come here to read. I can’t begin to tell you the number of books I’ve read here. Oliver puts his hands in the water.
It's freezing cold!  40.
The spring is in the mountains, the Alpi Orobie. The water comes straight down from there. Oliver freshens up his face with this water.
Do you like being alone?
No one likes being alone. But I’ve learned how to live with it.
Are you always so wise? So very wise?

I’m not wise at all. I told you, I know nothing. I know books, and I know how to string words together - it doesn’t mean I know how to speak about the things - about the things that matter most to me.
But you’re doing it now - in a way.

Yes, in a way - that’s how I always say things: in a way. Staring out down on the on the tips to his feet at the view so as not to look at him, ELIO sits grass. OLIVER crouches a few yards away from ELIO of his toes, as if at any moment he might spring and go back to the bicycles. ELIO (CONT’D) I come here to escape the known world.
I like the way you say things. Why are you always putting yourself down?
(shrugging) I don’t know. So you won’t, I suppose.

Are you so scared of what others think? Or what I think? ELIO shakes his head. OLIVER waits for ELIO to say something. He stares at him.  41. In the silence of the moment, ELIO stares back. It is the first time ELIO has dared to stare back at OLIVER openly. Before this moment he has always cast a glance, then look away from Oliver’s steely gaze. It is as if, finally, ELI saying to Oliver: This is who I am, this is who you are, is what I want. He stares back with an I-dare-you-to-kiss gaze. OLIVER (CONT’D) You’re making things very difficult for me. ELIO doesn’t back down. Neither does OLIVER.
Why am I making things difficult?
Because it would be very wrong.
Would? OLIVER sits down on the grass, then lies down on his back his arms under his head, staring at the sky.
Yes, would. I’m not going to pretend this hasn’t crossed my mind.
I’d be the last to know.
Well, it has. There! What did you think was going on?
Going on? Nothing...nothing. After a long silence:

I see. You've got it wrong, my friend - if it makes you feel better, I have to hold back. It’s time you learned to do that too. Each leaning on one arm, both stare out at the view. OLIVER (CONT’D) You're the luckiest kid in the world.  42.
(in something of a mocking tone) You don’t know the half of it. OLIVER thinks about this. Then ELIO blurts out: ELIO (CONT’D) So much of it is wrong.
What? Your family?
That too.

Us, you mean? ELIO doesn’t reply. OLIVER moves up close to him. Very cl He stares right in Elio’s face, as though he likes Elio’s face and wants to study it, linger on it. OLIVER touches Elio’s lower lip with his finger, lets it travel left and right, then right and left again. OLIVER smiles at ELIO as he lies there, and that very smile fill ELIO with a kind of apprehension about what will happen n What happens next is that OLIVER brings his lips to Elio’ mouth in a warm I’1l-meet-you-halfway-but-no-further kiss conciliatory kiss. ELIO’s return kiss is so famished he l himself in it. OLIVER (CONT’D) (afterwards) Better now? ELIO doesn’t answer. He kisses OLIVER again, lifting his face, as if to discover more, know more. Even with their faces touching, their bodies are angles apart. ELIO lifts knee as if to face OLIVER. OLIVER (CONT’D) I think we should go.
Not yet.
We can’t do this - I know myself. So far we’ve behaved. We’ve been good. Neither of us has done anything to feel ashamed of. Let’s keep it that way. I want to be good.  59 60 43.

Don’t be. I don’t care. Who is to know? ELIO reaches for OLIVER in a quick, desperate move, lets hand rest on Oliver’s crotch. OLIVER doesn’t move. With t composure, in a gesture that is both gentle and commandin he brings his own hand there, letting it rest on Elio’s f second. He twines his fingers into Elio’s, then lifts his hand. A moment of silence. ELIO (CONT’D) (suddenly abashed by his own action) Did I offend you?
Just don’t. He gives Elio his hand and helps him stand up. He pulls u his shirt to examine the scrape. OLIVER (CONT’D) I should make sure it doesn’t get infected.
We can stop by the pharmacist on the way back.
They glide down the slope on their bikes, with wind in th hair.
We’1ll never speak again, you know..
Don’t say that.
I just know it. We’1ll chit-chat, chit-chat, chit-chat. And the funny thing is, I can live with that.
You just rhymed.

Before dessert, as MAFALDA is clearing away the plates, a as the others are pre-occupied with a conversation about Antonello da Messina, ELIO feels a warm, bare foot casual brush his. ELIO is in the kitchen looking for ice to stop his nose bleeding, but the freezer is empty.

Later. In a very tight and confined space beside the livi room is the Perlman bar. ELIO is sitting on the floor, hi head tilted back, and is holding a napkin full of ice - n mixture of blood and water - on his nose. Beside him is a ice bucket.
Elio! Where are you?  45. OLIVER is the bocchirale [hallway], looking for him. Elio waves from the bar. Oliver goes over to him. ELIO smiles ruefully. OLIVER (CONT’D) Was it my fault?
I’m a mess, aren’t I?
I guess. The ancients said it never hurts to be bled from time to time.

Sit for a second. ELIO shifts a little to make room. The place is very tigh his bare feet touch Oliver's ankles for a moment. OLIVER takes Elio's feet in his hands and begins massagin them, pulling on his toes until they crack. ELIO cries ou mingled pleasure and pain. ELIO (CONT’D) Where did you learn to do that?
My Jewish grandmother. She did it all the time to us. Elio looks again at Oliver’s necklace with the Star of Da on his chest.
I have one of those.
You don’t ever wear it?
My mother says we are Jews of discretion.
I guess that fits your mom...
You're going to kill me, you know that? Ouch!
(giving a final tug to one of Elio’s big toes, and getting up) I hope not.  63 64 46. OLIVER (CONT’D) Are you going to be okay?
I’ll get over it.
Come on, stand up. Lie on the couch, rest a little. I’11l stick around. Oliver helps Elio up.
In the bocchirale OLIVER meets the sisters MARZIA and CHI They’ re giggling.
How is he? Will he live?
I think so. He gave me a scare. Bleeding all over the dining table.
